message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The prolonged second stage of labor and vacuum-assisted vaginal delivery increases the risk of cephalohematoma, which presents as a soft, nonpulsatile swelling that does not cross suture lines. Lipoma and epidermoid cysts are not typically present at birth, and subgaleal hemorrhage would present as a diffuse swelling without clear borders.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The prolonged second stage of labor and vacuum-assisted delivery increases the risk of cephalohematoma, which presents as a soft, nonpulsatile swelling over one of the cranial bones that does not cross the suture lines. None of the other options are consistent with the presentation, and the other exam findings are normal.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location and nonpulsatile nature of the swelling suggest a cephalohematoma, which is a collection of blood underneath the periosteum of the skull. The fact that it does not cross suture lines is also suggestive. Lipoma and epidermoid cysts are not typically present at birth, and subgaleal hemorrhage usually presents with diffuse swelling and a boggy texture.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A cephalohematoma is a collection of blood beneath the periosteum of the skull. It does not cross the suture lines, is nonpulsatile, and can occur after vacuum-assisted delivery, which fits the presentation of the patient. A lipoma is a benign fatty mass that is not typically present at birth. A subgaleal hemorrhage is a collection of blood within the subgaleal space, which is beneath the galea aponeurotica, and is typically a result of head trauma. An epidermoid cyst is a slow-growing cyst that is typically asymptomatic and is caused by epidermal cells that are trapped during embryonic development.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of a soft, nonpulsatile swelling over the left parietal bone that does not cross suture lines suggests a cephalohematoma. A lipoma and epidermoid cyst are not related to the skull, and subgaleal hemorrhage would be more diffuse and extend beyond sutures.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The prolonged second stage of labor and vacuum-assisted delivery put the child at risk for cephalohematoma. The soft, nonpulsatile swelling that does not cross suture lines is typical of cephalohematoma. Lipoma and Epidermoid cysts are unlikely in a newborn and Subgaleal hemorrhages present with diffuse swelling of the scalp.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The soft, nonpulsatile swelling over the left parietal bone that does not cross suture lines suggests a cephalohematoma, which is a common birth injury caused by bleeding beneath the periosteum of the skull. Lipomas and epidermoid cysts do not occur at birth and a subgaleal hemorrhage would cross suture lines.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The prolonged second stage of labor and vacuum-assisted vaginal delivery increase the risk of injury to the baby's head. Cephalohematoma is a collection of blood between the skull and periosteum that does not cross suture lines. It is a common complication of vacuum-assisted delivery.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location, shape, and timing of the appearance of the swelling suggest a cephalohematoma, which is a collection of blood underneath the periosteum of the skull bone. Lipoma and epidermoid cyst are unlikely to be present at birth, while subgaleal hemorrhage typically crosses suture lines.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient had a vacuum-assisted vaginal delivery, which puts the neonate at risk for cephalohematoma, a collection of blood between the skull and periosteum that does not cross suture lines. All other options would not have this presentation.
